Thanks!
This PR need wait for all azure pipelines PRs merge first, then must merge before update sonic-swss-common submodule.

@lixiaoyuner, @qiluo-msft why is this PR needs to go into 202205 branch? Please elaborate.

> @lixiaoyuner, @qiluo-msft why is this PR needs to go into 202205 branch? Please elaborate.

Hi @yxieca, this PR is to upgrade the k8s components version from 1.21 to 1.22 so that the SONiC can join our current k8s cluster as worker. As Guohan suggested, we will try to pilot Container Upgrade by K8s project on 202205 branch.

@vboykox Do we know why we started seeing this issue only recently? I believe some recent commits might have exposed this issue. Do you suspect any commit?
@vboykox  can you check the test failure?

> @vboykox Do we know why we started seeing this issue only recently? I believe some recent commits might have exposed this issue. Do you suspect any commit?

@dgsudharsan  I have not done such analysis, but I would look for changes in startup
times/order of other services and possibly on bootchart integration.
For any change that could put interface-config and bgp closer at startup - like database startup times improvement.

I know about the issue since the mid of June. It reproduces approx once-twice in two weeks considering everyday runs. Can not say if there was any recent change in the frequency.

Are you also observing the issue?

> > @vboykox Do we know why we started seeing this issue only recently? I believe some recent commits might have exposed this issue. Do you suspect any commit?
> 
> @dgsudharsan I have not done such analysis, but I would look for changes in startup times/order of other services and possibly on bootchart integration. For any change that could put interface-config and bgp closer at startup - like database startup times improvement.
> 
> I know about the issue since the mid of June. It reproduces approx once-twice in two weeks considering everyday runs. Can not say if there was any recent change in the frequency.
> 
> Are you also observing the issue?

Yes we are also observing the same issue only recently but it doesn't reproduce that frequently as you mentioned.

wondering this change can be be handle in platform code ?  Not all vendors/platform have br1 define on supervisor. 

Similar to creation of eth1-midplane is platform/vendor specific.

> wondering this change can be be handle in platform code ? Not all vendors/platform have br1 define on supervisor.
> 
> Similar to creation of eth1-midplane is platform/vendor specific.

I don't think we can easily move that change in platform code because all namespaces are created and destroyed here, that's the reason the entire logic was moved from interface-config to database.sh in #10500 

Here we assume `br1` exists (same as `eth1-midplane`). If there is no consensus on the name of the bridge we can add that in `chassisdb.conf` like we do for `midplane_subnet`.

> > wondering this change can be be handle in platform code ? Not all vendors/platform have br1 define on supervisor.
> > Similar to creation of eth1-midplane is platform/vendor specific.
> 
> I don't think we can easily move that change in platform code because all namespaces are created and destroyed here, that's the reason the entire logic was moved from interface-config to database.sh in #10500
> 
> Here we assume `br1` exists (same as `eth1-midplane`). If there is no consensus on the name of the bridge we can add that in `chassisdb.conf` like we do for `midplane_subnet`.

Hi @mlorrillere, not all platform need a software bridge  to communicate between LC and Sup. So they dont need to create `br1`.  On platforms which don't create the bridge we create an `eth1-midplane` interface. Wondering on the platfrom which need a software bridge we care create a bridge with name `eth1-midplane` ?

> > > wondering this change can be be handle in platform code ? Not all vendors/platform have br1 define on supervisor.
> > > Similar to creation of eth1-midplane is platform/vendor specific.
> > 
> > 
> > I don't think we can easily move that change in platform code because all namespaces are created and destroyed here, that's the reason the entire logic was moved from interface-config to database.sh in #10500
> > Here we assume `br1` exists (same as `eth1-midplane`). If there is no consensus on the name of the bridge we can add that in `chassisdb.conf` like we do for `midplane_subnet`.
> 
> Hi @mlorrillere, not all platform need a software bridge to communicate between LC and Sup. So they dont need to create `br1`. On platforms which don't create the bridge we create an `eth1-midplane` interface. Wondering on the platfrom which need a software bridge we care create a bridge with name `eth1-midplane` ?

`eth1-midplane` is the name of the interface on the linecard side. On the sup side the endpoint of the `eth1-midplane` of all linecards is added to `br1`.

In practice this PR is already a noop on platforms that don't have `br1` because this code is conditional on `midplane_subnet` being defined in `chassisdb.conf` of the sup (which is usually not defined, hence why it is added to `device/arista/x86_64-arista_7800_sup/chassisdb.conf`). Since this is not obvious, an alternative could be to add a `midplane_bridge=br1` to `chassisdb.conf`, that way we could clearly see which part of the code is run on the sup/linecard.

As discussed offline, we will keep `br1` in this PR as changing the name of the bridge requires updating Arista's platform modules. We will update Arista platform modules to create the bridge as `eth1-midplane` and update docker_image_ctl.j2 when we bump-up sonic-platform-modules-arista.

Need merge this issue for 202205.

I went through the list of patches that were removed in the FRR upgrade https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/10691. 

There is one patch of concern.

src/sonic-frr/patch/0009-Link-local-scope-was-not-set-while-binding-socket-for-bgp-ipv6-link-local-neighbors.patch

In FRR
Introduced: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-frr/commit/0b6d35324ef3fd2b4d5997103795cad73eb72954

Reverted: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-frr/commit/6740a191adb7e330370d568c9192624a22b008cb (https://github.com/FRRouting/frr/pull/8430)

However, this patch was introduced in SONiC but never reverted. Now with upgrading to FRR and without this patch won’t we be facing issues?

> I went through the list of patches that were removed in the FRR upgrade #10691.
> 
> There is one patch of concern.
> 
> src/sonic-frr/patch/0009-Link-local-scope-was-not-set-while-binding-socket-for-bgp-ipv6-link-local-neighbors.patch
> 
> In FRR Introduced: [sonic-net/sonic-frr@0b6d353](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-frr/commit/0b6d35324ef3fd2b4d5997103795cad73eb72954)
> 
> Reverted: [sonic-net/sonic-frr@6740a19](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-frr/commit/6740a191adb7e330370d568c9192624a22b008cb) ([FRRouting/frr#8430](https://github.com/FRRouting/frr/pull/8430))
> 
> However, this patch was introduced in SONiC but never reverted. Now with upgrading to FRR and without this patch won’t we be facing issues?

Please note that patch file 0009-Link-local-scope.. has been replaced with [0008-Link-local-scope..](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/10691/files#diff-cd5cfc41e5f3583085d4632c591a487cb2ec39b9b6812d7f475a24c6c63fd5a6):

Regarding the changes in the old [0009-Link-local-scope](https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-buildimage/pull/10691/files#diff-4aece4165cdf7dac0b7df9d3d9cf79980fdb5f8f2445fcec12777c9cc11aa251) patch file, there were two changes originally. One of the changes (in bgp_update_address()) has been carried to the new patch file, and the other change (in bgp_zebra_nexthop_set()) is already present in the [8.2.2 code](https://github.com/FRRouting/frr/blob/79188bf710e92acf42fb5b9b0a2e9593a5ee9b05/bgpd/bgp_zebra.c#L791). I hope this clarifies.
/easycla

I checked this PR and it's not conflict with the recent change in libswsscommon.
Because this project is a pure python project and not using pubsub from swsscommon, so the signal handler in this PR will not be blocked by the infinite loop in pubsub.

`"FAILED:dut:Longest downtime period must be less then 200 seconds. It was 0:03:50.634783", `

Downtime being exceeded by 30s is unexpected and may not be termed flaky. Please look at the failures.

@vaibhavhd looks like this PR won't pass tests without sonic-utilities update as well as sonic-utilities update PR won't pass tests without this PR. Updated sonic-utilities here and checking results.

The tests failed with:
`        "FAILED:dut:Longest downtime period must be less then 200 seconds. It was 0:03:43.843506", `

I am curious now why the same PR on 202012 (https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/pull/10511) consistently passed and this one on master consistently failed.
Particularly when this PR is meant to improve the warmboot flow.


Update: I just realized that the PR on 202012 did not run tests, and hence it showed up as passing. So basically we don't know if this test would have passed/failed on 202012.

There is a problem that hostcfgd blocks forever and does not react to SIGTERM causing a delay in warm boot.
When hitting this line  https://github.com/Azure/sonic-buildimage/blob/master/src/sonic-host-services/scripts/hostcfgd#L1241 .

Example:

```
>>> from swsscommon import swsscommon
>>> c=swsscommon.ConfigDBConnector()
>>> c.subscribe('A', lambda a: None)
>>> c.connect()
>>> c.listen()


^C^C^C^C
```
@qiluo-msft This looks like a swss-common issue.

This wasn't seen for some reason during 500 warm boot tests on 202012 since warm reboot is executed early enough before hostcfgd stucks in a listen().
